awd_titl_txt: CSR:Medium:Collaborative Research: An Analytical Approach to Quantifying Availability (AQUA) for Cloud Resource Provisioning and Allocation
awd_abstract_narration:
Cloud computing will significantly transform the landscape of the IT industry and also impact the economy and society in many ways. The reliability and availability of cloud services, affected by various hardware and software component failures, becomes increasingly more critical, as government agencies, business and people are expected to rely more and more on these services. Lack of a guaranteed high availability of cloud services and applications is considered by many IT professionals as the top concern for preventing a successful implementation of cloud services, followed by device based security and cloud application performance. This project aims to predict the service availability for a given setting, and design effective resource provisioning and allocation algorithms to guarantee a high availability level required by cloud services. The project is expected to significantly advance the state-of-the-art by offering deep insights into the knowledge about accurate prediction and cost-effective guarantee of availability/reliability of cloud services. The outputs from this project can be used to 1) improve service availability, performance and resource utilization while minimizing the cost of overprovisioning, 2) reduce huge losses in revenue and productivity due to service outages while enabling new (mission-critical) applications and services.

The existing approaches to ensuring availability are qualitative in that they use heuristics to duplicate data or restrict the number of virtual machines (VMs) that should be placed in the same rack/server to improve reliability/availability of cloud services. However, it is essential to be able to quantify availability for a given setting. Quantifying availability for an often finite service duration via analysis (as opposed to measurement or qualitative evaluation) requires transient, instead of steady state probability analysis based on a wide range of failure and repair/backup models. This project takes a holistic approach to addressing the open challenges via both rigorous analysis and extensive experiments. More specifically, the project leverages two large-scale HPC/Cloud production systems at PI?s institutions to generate a rich set of fine-grained data about physical component failures (which is not available in the public domain). The data is then analyzed to build and verify/validate failure models. Based on the failure models and for a given Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) request for n virtual machines (VMs), a service duration of t time units and a desired availability level a < 1, the project develops an analytical model to predict the availability that can be achieved for the service duration (t), if an additional k backup VMs are allocated. The project also develops cost-effective, multi-objective optimization based cloud resource provisioning and allocation algorithms that determine the appropriate value for k (and the placement of these n+k VMs) in order to achieve the required availability level a.

por.por_cntn:
Our research offers deep insights into factors affecting the availability in cloud computing, and producing and disseminating analytic models and computational tools, as well as cost-effective resource provisioning and allocation methods (middleware and algorithms) that will be useful to achieve a high availability level. Accurate analytic techniques developed in this project based on sample path analysis, currently produce fast and accurate estimation of the availability. Birth-death processes are typically used to depict the underlying server failures and repairs which drive availability and while steady-state probabilities had already been derived for such processes involving server failures and repairs, they are likely to be highly inaccurate under transience.

We have demonstrated that steady-state cannot be guaranteed within the lifespan of typical cloud contracts, diminishing the effectiveness of prior simplistic prediction techniques. Therefore, our probability distribution estimation technique for a system in transience serves an essential purpose in the design, delivery and management of these services and can also be a useful tool to solve complex models in other disciplines. Further, we have developed separate techniques to take advantage of scenarios where early warning signs are evident prior to full failure of a virtual machine (VM), with the VM continuing to function even while emitting these warning signals. This leads to even greater accuracy in the overall prediction of availability. In fact, even for a high level of precision, we have demonstrated that our Sample Path Randomization (SPR) algorithm converges fast with a very modest growth in sample size and as such, it  can be used in real-time settings for resource provisioning in cloud datacenters.

More specifically, we have first developed the predicted availability of cloud services, along with the availability models and VM provisioning and allocation algorithms, which we then used to improve Service Level Agreement (SLA) guarantee on service availability. We have created a tool to customize contract constructs for each client, a key consideration given the current heterogeneity in cloud services and client expectations regarding service. Our algorithms incorporate learning from real data streams generated from the IT system, which includes the state of the system, in the form of failures and repairs, and then optimizes resource provisioning and the design of the prices and penalties.  The tool  can aid a provider during contract negotiations on these design constructs by establishing the baseline price from which she should start to negotiate with a client in a principal-agent game theoretic context. We have also developed an algorithm to establish the minimum price a provider should charge for a given required service level and penalty. Therefore, our work serves as the first steps required in the economic modeling of the service contracts and related negotiation processes, affecting the future success of the contract. Our work is the first to model the availability issue in the cloud resource allocation and pricing process, with our inventory management tool cost-effectively mitigating the service disruption risk faced by the end user.

To provision availability in data centers which has multiple domains with heterogeneous failure and repair processes and various topologies, we have also provided a framework to concisely describe a data center topology and estimate the downtime distribution when supporting network function virtualization. Furthermore, to enable distributed network function virtualization mapping with availability guarantee, we have proposed algorithms to provision availability with on- and off-site backups, respectively. 

In a broader sense, cloud computing continues to greatly transform all sectors of the global economy by improving productivity and agility while reducing costs, among other benefits. However, cloud computing also continues to grapple with serious issues related to availability/reliability and security which affects its public trust, market sentiment and its wider adoption. Our research helps improve the availability/reliability of cloud services, and thus benefits both existing and emerging users and applications, potentially reducing millions of dollars of losses in revenue and productivity due to service outages, and avoiding wasted energy consumed by interrupted jobs (as some may have to be restarted all over again). As the project involved a junior woman faculty (S. Smith) as a Co-PI, and a woman PhD student (Z. Yang) as an RA who has since graduated and joined Google as a Software Engineer, the project has increased the participation of women in science, technology and engineering. This is especially critical in computer science, which has a poor track record when compared to some of the other scientific disciplines with respect to women pursuing careers.
